awd_abstract_narration:
This project will use in tandem two large radio antennas located at the Owens Valley Radio Observatory to monitor a sample of nearby active stars for radio bursts associated with large stellar flares or coronal mass ejections (CMEs).  The necessary custom electronic hardware to process the signals will be constructed, and advantage will be taken of new receivers on the telescopes; all of these are designed to permit broad spectral bandwidth observations, which give high sensitivity, as well as high time resolution.  The search for radio bursts will be carried out in a real-time, automated fashion.

Scientific targets include young stellar objects (YSOs), close binary stars, and active M dwarf stars.    The target sample consists of 15 stars, and these will be monitored for 2.5 years, accumulating 500 hours of observation time per star.  This will give a unique data set for assessing coronal and interplanetary conditions around active stars and their orbiting planetary systems.  There will be simultaneous low frequency coverage for every target observed, by using a new low frequency array at Owens Valley.  The result will be observations spanning 2 decades of frequency (28 MHz to 6 GHz), thus tracking coronal mass ejection events from the stellar corona into the interplanetary medium.  Simultaneous optical spectroscopic observations will also be made, as well as triggered VLBI follow-up observations.

These observations should register substantial broader impacts in the form of public interest, which is particularly keen around the current time of Solar maximum.  The project team is active in public outreach lectures and other activities.  

Funding for this project is being provided by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences through its Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

Many classes of stars produce flares that are several orders of magnitude more luminous and frequent than any produced on the Sun. Such activity can have a profound impact on the planetary systems orbiting such stars, with higher X-ray and ultraviolet irradiation leading to heating of the upper planetary atmosphere, resulting in photochemical reactions leading to significant atmospheric loss. In particular, studies of terrestrial planets in the habitable zone of M dwarfs, possibly the most abundant Earth-like planets in the solar neighborhood, suggest that large flares and CMEs can lead to catastrophic loss of the atmosphere of such planets.

However, these theoretical exercises are hampered by the complete absence of quantitative data on the interplanetary shocks generated by stellar CMEs and the associated stellar wind density, speed, and magnetic field disturbances at or near the habitable zone of orbiting terrestrial planets. Rather, gross assumptions extrapolated from our understanding of solar CMEs must be made, which are likely to be incorrect. The Starburst project has amassed the first significant sample of quantitative data on the bulk motion of plasma in the coronae of nearby M dwarfs, through detection of 13 radio bursts via programs executed as part of this project.THese bursts provide direct diagnostic data on the plasma conditions, magnetic field strength, velocities and energetics of large flares and CMEs around nearby active stars. Simultaneously, on the path to this result, a very novel and versatile digital system has been developed, the design of which is rapidly being adopted by other radio instruments.

Broader Impact

The study of the active Sun captures the imagination of the wider public, with this public interest particularly keen around the time of Solar maximum, as is the case in 2012-2013. This interest is reinforced by the potential impact on power grids and communications during large flares and CMEs, but also by the beautiful images returned from both space- and ground-based observatories of such flares and CMEs and the beautiful aurorae that can often ensue. The Starburst program offers the exciting potential of opening a new window on similar activity on other stars, with the scale of the flares found on such stars often dwarfing anything detected from the Sun. The impact of such activity on the atmospheres and potential biospheres of orbiting planets is certainly a topic that can capture the public’s attention.In parallel, the digital systems and libraries developed as part of this project is already having significant impact on the efforts of the community to deliver cost-effective and versatile digital hardware.
